results.title: Hunter Schafer went on live to expose Silq
results.brief_description: Trans actress and model Hunter Schafer went live on Instagram to expose Silq, a nightclub in Düsseldorf, for refusing her assistant entry because she is trans. Schafer connected with up to 30.1K of her followers in real time to call out the club as “not safe for transgender people”. @schaferfiles, a Twitter fan account for the actress, ensured that Schafer’s broadcast could be accessed beyond the live stream, screen recording and reposting the video to Twitter. The viral nature of Schafer’s video demonstrates the power of social media as a tool for activism.
results.title_for_label: Hunter Schafer went on live to expose Silq
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Trans actress and model Hunter Schafer went live on Instagram to expose Silq, a nightclub in Düsseldorf, for refusing her assistant entry because she is trans. Schafer connected with up to 30.1K of her followers in real time to call out the club as “not safe for transgender people”. @schaferfiles, a Twitter fan account for the actress, ensured that Schafer’s broadcast could be accessed beyond the live stream, screen recording and reposting the video to Twitter. The viral nature of Schafer’s video demonstrates the power of social media as a tool for activism.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: 'Screen It' 2011 - Winners
results.brief_description:
‘Screen It’ was Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students, run by ACMI for 16 years to 2019.

Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fostered a new generation of young media makers. In 2011 budding young film and game-makers took up the challenge of creating their own short film or game in response to the theme ‘Respect.’

Witness first-hand the amazing winning entries of the 2011 Screen It competition!
results.description:
‘Screen It’ was Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students, run by ACMI for 16 years to 2019.

Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fostered a new generation of young media makers. In 2011 budding young film and game-makers took up the challenge of creating their own short film or game in response to the theme ‘Respect.’

Witness first-hand the amazing winning entries of the 2011 Screen It competition!

results.title: The World As We Know It
results.creator_credit: Sunbury Downs College and Shannon Castle
results.brief_description:
A figure, shown by stop-motion animation, much like a zombie, walks through a world in pain. The Earth and people on it are being treated unfairly. Only if the figure wakes up to the fact that we need to respect the world and its inhabitants will the world become a better place.
Under the category ‘Secondary Animation’, Sunbury Downs College’s Shannon Castle, Year 9, was the Screen It 2011 winner.

results.title: Twin [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Lee and James Ruse Agricultural High
results.brief_description:
‘Twin’ is a videogame that highlights the importance of self-respect. It is based upon the Hero’s search for those who took away his ‘colour’. As his colour has been taken away, he has been reduced to his black and white form; his own being is split into two. The Hero realises his colour was in fact not stolen and by being able to overcome the puzzles and challenges brought by each level, the Hero begins to respect himself and is ultimately able to retrieve his ‘colours.’

A 2D problem solving/puzzle showing respect starts with self. This trailer illustrates how the game is played.
Under the category ‘Secondary Games’, James Ruse Agricultural High School’s Nicholas Lee, Year 12, was the Screen It 2011 winner.

results.title: The Respect Quest [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Christopher Halse, Liam Blake and Tea Tree Gully Primary School
results.brief_description:
Time Monsters are spreading disrespect in the community and causing havoc. Help local villagers and elders restore respect by defeating the Time Monsters with a magic boomerang. Jump on platforms, collect coins and explore through the mountains of time. Money gained on the quest will help rebuild the villages after respect is restored.

This trailer illustrates how the game is played.
Under the category ‘Primary Games’, Tea Tree Gully Primary School’s Liam Blake and Christopher Halse, Grade 5, were the Screen It 2011 winners.

results.title: The Locket
results.brief_description:
It would be easy to discard a worthless, old locket found on the beach but, out of respect for a serviceman in a black and white photo, an old man embarks on a journey to return the memento to its original owner. He travels a long way from his lonely, daily routine and unearths respect for himself and a fallen solider. ‘The Locket’ is a snapshot of a life we don’t know we’re in until something – or someone – snaps you out of it.
Cast Includes: John Murphy, Iris Whitakker, David Jellie, Victoria Upward, Gomer Jones and Nadine Crichton.
Under the category ‘Secondary Live Action’, this independent entry by Blake Borcich, Year 10, was the Screen It 2011 winner.

results.title: Caught In The Crowd
results.creator_credit: India Thompson and Norwood Primary School
results.brief_description:
Piper and Nick were best friends from a young age but as they grew up, Piper became one of the most popular girls in the school and studious Nick fell into the nerdy group. School bullies harass Nick while Piper looks on concerned. She is torn when Nick calls to her for help. Will Piper risk her popularity to respect their life-long friendship, or will she be caught in the crowd?
Written and directed by India Thompson with Film Support by Michael Hilbert and Sue Chapple. Cast includes: Piper Adams, Nicholas House, Emma Johnstone and Cameron Wicks.
Under the category ‘Primary Live Action’, Norwood Primary School’s 5/6 Chapple/Dennis class were the Screen It 2011 winners.

results.title: Buzz Off
results.brief_description:
This clay-animated story is about respect for others who are different or have different cultures. Overcome by Bees, The Jewel Beetles must flee their home to find a safe place to live. Forced to brave a treacherous river and evade hungry predators, the Jewel Beetles reach the safety of Grasshopper Land. They overhear a debate between two grasshoppers. One grasshopper believes that beetles would bring new perspectives and cultures to Grasshopper Land, while the other grasshopper, fearing change, thinks the beetles don’t belong. Intolerance or acceptance will determine the Jewel Beetles’ fate.
Under the category ‘Primary Animation’, Yarraville West Primary School’s 5/6 Film Team were the Screen It 2011 winners.

results.title: Frank Eidlitz Collection
results.material_description: 2x 800ft 16mm; 3x 200ft 16mm; 5x 100ft 16mm; 1x 800ft 35mm on core 'Raga Doll'; 1x "half 7 1/5 track, 7mins" magnetic tape
results.brief_description:
The Frank Eidlitz Collection contains the 16mm and 35mm film work of graphic designer and visual artist Frank Eidlitz (1923–1997), predominantly made during a Winston Churchill Fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge in 1966. The collection contains Eidlitz’s experiments with light, movement and technology in film.

Frank Eidlitz was born and raised in Hungary and studied at the Royal Academy of Art in Budapest. He emigrated to Australia in 1948 and by 1955 had begun his graphic design career in Melbourne, working first with Atlas Publications. He became art director at USP Benson in 1957, where he would remain until 1965.

In 1964, Eidlitz designed a highly acclaimed campaign for Shell, which consisted of a series of 24 posters using the emblem of an arrow – designed to convey movement, power and speed. His early work as a graphic designer and visual artist was informed by an interest in kinetic art. In an article that appeared in ‘Print’ magazine in 1967, Eidlitz is quoted as saying, “To me kinetics express the idea of space and time simultaneously, and by inviting the spectator to participate, the viewer becomes part of the artist’s creation and experiment. Why should art remain static when life and nature have a perpetual motion?”

In 1965, Eidlitz exhibited a collection of geometric and abstract paintings that experimented with optical illusion, entitled ‘Perceptual Abstractions’ at the Museum of Modern Art and Design, Melbourne. The gallery was run by John Reed, and was a precursor to the Heide Museum of Modern Art, Bulleen. The series of paintings had been commissioned by USP Benson to decorate the company’s new headquarters in South Melbourne.

Later that year, Eidlitz received a Winston Churchill Fellowship and travelled to the United States, with the intention of studying with influential Hungarian-American artist Gyorgy Kepes at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge. Eidlitz spent 1966 living between MIT and New York.

This collection of films was made during Eidlitz’s time in the US and contains his experiments with light, movement and technology. Informed by his interests in kinetic and optical art, these early film experiments mark a shift in Eidlitz’s work, incorporating science and technology into his perceptual abstractions.

The film reels in this collection contain offcuts and experiments, as well as completed projects including ‘Raga Doll’ and ‘Calder’, both of which were screened in Melbourne and Sydney upon Eidlitz’s return to Australia in 1967. Inspired by his introduction to new technology and experimental uses of photography and film in the US, as well as the teachings of Kepes, Eidlitz was one of the first artists to use computer graphics as a medium in Australia during the 1970s. Following his fellowship in the US, Eidlitz held exhibitions throughout Australia, in Europe and in New York.

The Frank Eidlitz Collection was generously donated to ACMI by the Eidlitz family.

results.title: Brett Whiteley
results.brief_description:
The Frank Eidlitz Collection contains the 16mm and 35mm film work of graphic designer and visual artist Frank Eidlitz (1923–1997), predominantly made during a Winston Churchill Fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge in 1966. The collection contains Eidlitz’s experiments with light, movement and technology in film.

This short film by Frank Eidlitz shows a snippet of Australian artist Brett Whiteley at home with his wife Wendy and daughter Arkie. It was likely filmed in late 1966 or early 1967, before the Whiteleys moved to New York in late 1967. The film shows the artist and his family at home in the evening, reading the newspaper and watching television. Whiteley’s paintings line the walls of the living space, including ‘Fidgeting with Infinity’ (1966), a large triptych painting that dominates the space.

The film is dark and at times blurry.

The film is dark and at times blurry.
description_for_label:
The Frank Eidlitz Collection contains the 16mm and 35mm film work of graphic designer and visual artist Frank Eidlitz (1923–1997), predominantly made during a Winston Churchill Fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge in 1966. The collection contains Eidlitz’s experiments with light, movement and technology in film.

This short film by Frank Eidlitz shows a snippet of Australian artist Brett Whiteley at home with his wife Wendy and daughter Arkie. It was likely filmed in late 1966 or early 1967, before the Whiteleys moved to New York in late 1967. The film shows the artist and his family at home in the evening, reading the newspaper and watching television. Whiteley’s paintings line the walls of the living space, including ‘Fidgeting with Infinity’ (1966), a large triptych painting that dominates the space.

The film is dark and at times blurry.
